title: 115_hr7105
content: The Act is titled the "Brian Tally VA Medical Care and Liability Improvement Act" and focuses on the accountability of health care providers at Department of Veterans Affairs facilities. The "Brian Tally VA Medical Care and Liability Improvement Act" amends Section 7316 of title 38, United States Code to treat contractors providing health care at VA facilities as if they were employees for liability purposes. If a contractor is sued, their insurance claim for medical malpractice is subrogated to the United States. The "Brian Tally VA Medical Care and Liability Improvement Act" allows the United States to take over insurance claims for medical malpractice lawsuits against contractors providing health care at VA facilities. If an individual is the defendant in at least three cases resulting in judgments against the United States, their authorization to provide health care at VA facilities will be revoked. The "Brian Tally VA Medical Care and Liability Improvement Act" allows the United States to handle insurance claims for medical malpractice lawsuits against contractors at VA facilities. If a defendant has three judgments against the US, their authorization to provide healthcare at VA facilities will be revoked. Notifications and outreach regarding Federal Tort Claims are required, including notifying state licensing entities and the National Practitioner Data Bank within 30 days of a judgment. The Secretary must also publish an explanation of rights on the Department's website. The Department's website must provide an explanation of an individual's rights regarding filing claims and time limits under the Act. The Under Secretary is required to take action against healthcare providers with three malpractice judgments. The Under Secretary must take action against healthcare providers with three malpractice judgments within a five-year period, as specified in section 7316 of this title. This includes judgments against the United States or settlements compromised by the United States, as determined by the Secretary. Additionally, care subject to civil actions resulting in judgments or settlements must be accounted for under this provision. The amendments made by this section apply to actions covered under section 7316 of title 38, United States Code, occurring after the enactment of this Act.
